ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I feel I am on the road to becoming a much better, more thoughtful actor, rather than just a convincing "performer." I have been given a very helpful "actor's toolkit" to keep with me at all times, not just when playing Shakespeare, but when tackling any kind of material. I feel I have been taught to develop a bit more of a backbone in defending my artistic choices.

This is one of the most rewarding and stimulating classes I have ever taken. If you commit to it and take in your stride all you are learning, it may prove one of the most transformative experiences of your undergraduate career.
How to think about approaching text and use it as a map. How to be more in my body and self while acting. How to get out of my own way.
This is the best class Ive taken at Yale by far

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I felt there was very little time to actually do group exercises together and bond as a collective. I understand that this class was specifically a studio format, but even so, I rarely felt connected to my classmates and it was only through James that we experienced shared memories. Ideally, I would have liked our class bonding to come from our relationships with one another and not as a mere byproduct of the teacher's 1-on-1 instruction with each actor.

The strength of this course was in James instruction, coupled with that of Bobbin, our TA. Their differences in style and expression of similar ideas was very compatible and allowed for different spaces and means by which to achieve your goal. I would have loved to have more opportunity for collaboration and discussion, and perhaps receiving ideas and feedback from class, not least to release some of the tension and intensity and put some of the play back into the performance aspect. But overall it was one of the most formative experiences I have had at Yale and wish I could take it again.

Strength: weekly tutorials with the TF were SO helpful because it was a less stressful environment to try things out

Weakness: there were not predetermined office hours. I suppose if we had emailed him we could have set up a meeting, but that made it feel like getting extra help or clarification was discouraged.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Unclear. This class is not for the faint of heart, or at least, not for actors with fragile egos. You will be challenged in this course and knocked down several pegs, oftentimes in ways that seem fruitless. So take it at your own risk, but I do think the class provides some important lessons on how to act more truthfully.

YES! Best acting class Ive ever taken. You learn so much but dont ever feel like youre busy learning; you just absorb. Ill be drawing on stuff from this course every time I act now for the rest of my life.
